title: b"`--colors` flag seems to be ignored, `%colors` doesn't work"
body:
b"See:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/57394/16251033/6a34f510-37d7-11e6-9092-29fe74cf605c.png)

I can't seem to get the no-color or LightBG schemes to work. I know there's a new color system in place, but

a) the old ones should be grandfathered in and still work
b) nocolor should still be available
c) the `%colors` magic still only lists the old ones and doesn't actually work."

title: b"Can't quit `less` without using Ctrl-C: pager quit is effectively broken."
body: b'If I run `!less <somefile>`, issuing `q` fails to quit it. I have to issue `Ctrl-C` to quit.  This is pretty problematic since `less` is used by the pager for long output.'

title: b'Terminal auto-scrolls with long input'
body:
b'It seems after the introduction of the new prompt-toolkit machinery, the terminal automatically scrolls up, always leaving a few blank lines at the bottom.  This is different from how both the shell and previous IPython worked, and effectively wastes useful vertical space:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/57394/14486345/1fc15f70-0111-11e6-9c36-78fac134367c.png)
'

title: b'TypeError on Shell Completion'
body:
b'I get the following error when attempting tab completion within `ipython` console:
```python
Python 2.7.11+ (default, Mar 30 2016, 21:00:42) 
Type "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.

IPython 5.0.0.dev -- An enhanced Interactive Python.
?         -> Introduction and overview of IPython's features.
%quickref -> Quick reference.
help      -> Python's own help system.
object?   -> Details about 'object', use 'object??' for extra details.

In [1]: dException in thread Thread-7:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/threading.py", line 801, in __bootstrap_inner
    self.run()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/threading.py", line 754, in run
    self.__target(*self.__args, **self.__kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/prompt_toolkit/interface.py", line 742, in run
    completions = list(buffer.completer.get_completions(document, complete_event))
  File "/home/bwillar0/projects/python/ipython/IPython/terminal/ptshell.py", line 55, in gets
    m = unicodedata.normalize('NFC', m)
TypeError: normalize() argument 2 must be unicode, not str
```

Changing line 55 of `ptshell.py` to 
```python
m = unicodedata.normalize('NFC', unicode(m))
```
works fine, but I'm not sure if that's really the problem.  Any ideas?'

title: b'Odd, broken buffering of internal messages...'
body:
b"Consider the following session (this is on master, right now at `51fa9ee`):

```
In [1]: alias_magic foo

In [2]: 1+2
Out[2]: 3

In [3]: exit
UsageError: the following arguments are required: targetdenali[~]>
```

My call to `alias_magic` was missing one argument, but the error message got completely swallowed (even though it's a print statement inside the `alias_magic` code). It only makes it to stdout at shutdown.  I tried with longer sessions, creating more errors, and they just keep piling up internally until the exit.  Very odd.

Ping @takluyver, I suspect this is also related to the recent ptoolkit work."

title: b'Confirm-on-exit broken on master'
body: b'This is a regression introduced by the new ptshell code, specifically [here](https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/master/IPython/terminal/ptshell.py#L260). It should honor the standard `c.TerminalInteractiveShell.confirm_exit = True` flag in `ipython_config.py`.\r\n\r\nPinging @takluyver...'

title: b'Auto-rewrite when autocall is on miscomputes the number of dashes to print and then messes output prompt positioning'
body:
b"Not sure what logic is doing this under the hood, but the problem is pretty obvious:

```
In [1]: autocall 
Automatic calling is: Smart

In [2]: print 1
-> print(1)
1

In [3]: print 1
------------> print(1)
1

In [4]: print 1
-----------------------> print(1)
1
```
On each successive call, more and more dashes get printed (and they aren't the right number even on the first call).  This is certainly a new bug, though I haven't bisected it yet.

Furthermore, once this has happened, the output prompt ends up mis-positioned:

```
In [10]: 3
  Out[10]: 3
```

My `sys_info`:

```
In [9]: print(sys_info())
{'commit_hash': 'aa586fd',
 'commit_source': 'repository',
 'default_encoding': 'UTF-8',
 'ipython_path': '/Users/fperez/dev/ipython/ipython/IPython',
 'ipython_version': '5.0.0.dev',
 'os_name': 'posix',
 'platform': 'Darwin-15.3.0-x86_64-i386-64bit',
 'sys_executable': '/Users/fperez/usr/conda/bin/python',
 'sys_platform': 'darwin',
 'sys_version': '3.5.1 |Continuum Analytics, Inc.| (default, Dec  7 2015, '
                '11:24:55) \n'
                '[GCC 4.2.1 (Apple Inc. build 5577)]'}
```"

title: b'Wrap colour sequences in debugger prompt in marker bytes'
body: b'Readline expects ANSI escapes in the prompt to be wrapped in \\x01 and \\x02 so that it can calculate the width.\r\n\r\nCloses gh-9243'

title: b'ipython tab completion always display all possibilities'
body:
b"In IPython interactive shell, when press 'TAB', will show some possibilities according your input, if possibilities are too much, will give question like this:

    In [1]: from <tab>
    Display all 497 possibilities? (y or n)

then you can press 'y' or 'n' to determine whether display them.


My problom is that when I use IPython, the question will be shown but **I never has chance to press any key, it will always show all the possibilities blow**.

I have tried IPython 2.4.1 and IPython 4.0.1 in different environment (linux & windows), always has this issue, this is very Annoying when use IPython.

Is this a bug of IPython or any other reasons?"

title: b"%%writefile ignores '>>>' at the beginning of lines"
body:
b"If I write the following in the code cell:
```
%%writefile test.txt
>>> fact(5)
120
```
I expect that the text after the %%writefile magic will be present in the text file literally. Instead, only the following is found in the textfile:
```
fact(5)
120
```
IPython probably first filters out the '>>>' string and then passes the result to the cell magic function.It behaves like this in both the notebook, and in the IPython console.  I do not think this is the expected behavior. "

title: b'Update to latest path.py package breaks ipython'
body:
b'Updating to the latest [`path.py` package](https://github.com/jaraco/path.py), which is a dependency of [`pickleshare`](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pickleshare), causes ipython to break (see error below).

Easiest solution is to downgrade to `path.py 7.7.1`, but ideally `pickleshare` should implement the corresponding fix, which I issued here: https://github.com/pickleshare/pickleshare/issues/8
The "problematic" change in `path.py` you can find here: https://github.com/jaraco/path.py/commit/62ccb7623d4d048af663f205e21c2ec3f24fa17d

Now, the real question is, should `pickleshare` be replaced with something else, as it doesn't look like an actively maintained project? Or should at least the currently working version for `path.py` be requested as a dependency by `ipython` ?

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/ipython", line 7, in <module>
    from IPython import start_ipython
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/IPython/__init__.py", line 48, in <module>
    from .terminal.embed import embed
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/IPython/terminal/embed.py", line 16, in <module>
    from IPython.core.interactiveshell import DummyMod
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/IPython/core/interactiveshell.py", line 31, in <module>
    from pickleshare import PickleShareDB
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pickleshare.py", line 41, in <module>
    from path import path as Path
ImportError: cannot import name path
```'

title: b'kernel_ready.Kernel triggered twice when creating a new notebook'
body: b'Any time you a pushed directly into a new notebook, the \'kernel_ready.Kernel\' is triggered twice from kernel.js. This usually happens when creating a new notebook or "making a copy" from within a running notebook.\r\n'

title: b'Multiple selector master checkbox has wrong logic'
body:
b'If you hand select a number of items in the dashboard and then use the master checkbox to deselect all of them, it does the opposite (it selects everything). The current behavior is backwards from other similar UIs (Gmail for example). To reproduce, put the dashboard in this state and click the top (master) checkbox:

![screen shot 2015-03-14 at 4 58 13 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/27600/6653495/82a1623a-ca6b-11e4-9e9c-c254f2bba4fe.png)

Here is a summary of the desired behavior when the master checkbox is clicked:

* If none selected, select all.
* If all selected, deselect all.
* If some selected, deselect all
'

title: b'Focus click problems with toolbar'
body: b"If the selected cell is not in the optimal scroll position when a toolbar button is clicked, the browser will jump to scroll the selected cell into view after the button is clicked. There are some other focus click bugs that have started to show up as well, but I haven't been able to reproduce them. We need to be *very* careful about this stuff..."

title: b'SelectMultiple widget does not always work'
body:
b'@bobbysan reported this in #5327 .

---

Selecting multiple items using the SelectMultiple widget does not work in some cases for me. If the selected options are highlighted using only the mouse (and are contiguous) it works fine. If selecting only apples and bananas (using Shift and Ctrl) in the example below it does not work. It will highlight/select the last item clicked. Please advise. Thanks.

```python
w = widgets.SelectMultiple(
    description="Fruits",
    options=['Apples', 'Oranges', 'Pears', 'Grapes', 'Peaches', 'Bananas'])
display(w)
```

My setup:
ipython-verson: 3.1.0-dev & 3.0.0 (tried both)
platform: windows 7 
'

title: b'nbconvert --to slides --post server reveal.js redirection not working'
body:
b'I am using ipython nbconvert to serve my notebooks as slides locally.

When I run ipython nbconvert --to slides --post serve my-notebook.ipynb the slides are not rendered correctly.

I have noticed in the log that a redirection is added to serve reveal.js:

`[NbConvertApp] Redirecting reveal.js requests to https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/reveal.js/2.5.0`

but https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/reveal.js/2.5.0 returns a 403 error.

title: b'No space between notification areas'
body: b'The notification area in the notebook page shows different areas. There used to be a small (4-5px) space between them when multiple were showing. That is now gone. This can be seen when opening a notebook, but is very hard to capture in a screen shot.'

title: b'Incorrect kernel reported on new install'
body: b'I helped someone install the 3.0 beta under python 2 lat week. When he opened a v3 notebook and it was updated, it worked fine, but the name of the kernel was "Kernel" rather than Python 2.'

title: b'In-notebook terminal rendering of certain whole-screen applications (like mc) is broken.'
body:
b"This is related to #7242, but not quite fixed by that PR...

On Chrome on Linux, if I set the Consolas font to being my monospaced font, when running mc (Midnight Commander) in the in-notebook terminal, the computation of the column width must be wrong, b/c the page misrenders:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/57394/6197637/d26ca638-b39d-11e4-8445-12a68b919157.png)

This is even more evident when an error box is drawn:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/57394/6197640/db82257c-b39d-11e4-85df-2279bee71cf8.png)

Checking the value of `Terminal.brokenBold` in the JS Console returns `true` with Consolas. Yet, the fix in #7242 isn't helping here.

For reference, switching to another monospaced font, such as DejaVu Sans Mono, fixes the problem. So at least there's a workaround.

But even if the bug is in Consolas, it would be nice if we could make it work correctly (if viable).  Regular terminal emulators don't exhibit this behavior.  In as much as possible, we want our terminal to match a 'real' terminal 100%.

Marking this for 3.1, as it's fairly obscure and there's an easy workaround for now."

title: b'`Ctrl-a` keybinding should go to term.js terminal'
body:
b"The `C-a` keybinding is the standard bash 'go to start of line' keybinding.  I don't know how easy it is to make sure we redirect it so the terminal (in the notebook environment) sees it. I suspect it's being captured by the browser as 'select all'.

I'm flagging this as 3.0 as I think it's a big usability issue. BUT, if it's hard to do, let's punt and retarget for later. I only think we should fix now if the fix is very straightforward.

ps - we probably should have a label for the notebook terminal component.  Not sure what we want to name it (same for the notebook editor)"

title: b'fix access to png width and height in nbconvert html basic template'
body:
b'When converting a notebook to html with `ipython nbconvert --to html test.ipynb`, I got an error, with the relevant part of the long error message being
```
  File "/Users/feist/Downloads/self_compile/ipython/IPython/nbconvert/exporters/../templates/html/basic.tpl", line 134, in <module>
    width={{output.metadata['png']['width']}}
  File "/opt/local/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.4/lib/python3.4/site-packages/jinja2/environment.py", line 378, in getitem
    return obj[argument]
jinja2.exceptions.UndefinedError: 'IPython.nbformat.notebooknode.NotebookNode object' has no attribute 'png'
```
As far as I can tell, `basic.tpl` should instead use `output.metadata['image/png']`. With that change (which this pull request provides), everything works.'

title: b'User interface tour broken.'

title: b'Two link objects with name conflicts'
body:
b"Right now we have two things called `link`:

* One in `traitlets` that links attributes of any `HasTraits` subclass.
* One in `widgets` that does a JS based link of any `Widget` subclass.

Their API is nearly identical and it is very common to import both at the same time. I spent about 2 hours tracking down a super subtle bug because I had both imported and didn't realize which one I was using.

I think we should consider naming the JS one to `jslink`."

The notebook will jump scroll the new cell out of view.'

title: b'Fix ultratb when there are non-ascii filenames present in a traceback'
body:
b"This solves the simple problem of running a file with non-ascii chars in
its name that contains an error of any kind in it.

Example: A file called `\xa8\xa2.py` with this content

    foo('a')

run it with `%run \xa8\xa2.py` and see a horrible error.

This was motivated by this SO post:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27834477/unicode-decode-error-report-in-spyder"

title: b'atomic write umask'
body:
b'Reported on gitter.im/ipython/ipython by @bigzachattack 

Sadly no one was on the chat at that time, too busy with a big bearded men 
dressed in red trying to smuggle things in our houses through the cheminee. 

```
I noticed today working in master, that any new notebook I create or copy has permissions
0o600 and ignores my umask. In IPython.utils.io.atomic_writing() uses mkstemp() to create
a temporary file for the atomic write. According to the python docs, mkstemp creates
files as 0o600.

After the write succeeds to the tmp file, _copy_metadata is called to copy the metadata
from the original file to destination file. It will throw an exception if there is no
source file. Thus when the notebook is copied into the notebook dir, it has
permissions 0o600.

Is this desired behavior, temporary, or a bug? I work in an environment where are default
permissions are 0o660 to allow for users to easily share information, so defaulting new
notebooks to 0o600 seriously inhibits this ability.
```'

<!--
import numpy as np
-->

I think the text editor look of not having this white spacing is simpler, so I propose adopting this in the notebook page as well. This will involve a few different things:

title: b'code fails to produce a figure in inline mode (but works in Qt4Agg backend)'
body:
b'The following code fails to produce a figure if using inline mode, but works fine on the Qt4Agg backend.

The problem appears when setting the xscale to log.

```python
%pylab inline
from matplotlib.patches import Arrow, ConnectionPatch

# This figure does not show up (even if xlimits are specified)
figure()
ax = gca()
xy1 = (0, 0) # non-positive starting coordinate
xy2 = (1, 1)
con = ConnectionPatch(xyA=xy1, xyB=xy2, coordsA="data", coordsB="data",
                      axesA=ax, axesB=ax)

ax.add_artist(con)
xscale('log')
```

I get the following message:

/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/IPython/core/formatters.py:239: FormatterWarning: Exception in image/png formatter: width and height must each be below 32768
  FormatterWarning,

Also see for reference: https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/issues/3932'

title: b'%run magic on ipynb continues after a cell has an exception'
body:
b"When you run an .ipynb file with the %run magic, and a cell generates an exception, the remaining cells continue to run. This can have unexpected outcomes as subsequent cells typically rely on results from the cell that generated the exception. It is also inconsistent with the behaviour of 'run all' when viewing a notebook and with the behaviour when running a .py file (probably .ipy also..).

It would be good at least to have the option to halt when an exception is thrown, but ihmo it'd probably be best to simply stop execution of the remaining cells if an exception is thrown.

I'm working on ipython 2.0.0 (the tag in the repo with that name) as I need the --script functionality (which at last check had been disabled in the head version), so apologies if this is resolved in the head version.

For the record, this is related to #4452"

title: b'Overriding X-Frame-Options improperly disables any X-Frame-Options'
body:
b"
Noticed this when deploying a setup and testing on the wrong domain I configured it for.

Example output from the Chrome console:

```
Invalid 'X-Frame-Options' header encountered when loading 'https://example.org/user-dafskljf/notebooks/Untitled.ipynb': 'ALLOW FROM example.com' is not a recognized directive. The header will be ignored.
```

Noting that the embedding still worked, I tried this on another domain. Now all domains are allowed. By default, if the header is not overridden, iframe embedding is disallowed. With a `X-Frame-Options` setting  in `tornado_options` though, if the syntax is wrong it allows it on *all* domains.

Originally I, @rgbkrk, was the one to introduce this into IPython within the last few months. I'm a bit sad to see I didn't handle it right. Note that this is related to #6862, in that we should be using CSP instead of X-Frame-Options."

title: b'IPython not setting exit status if script errors'
body:
b'I'm using the subprocess module (Popen) to run a script using IPython, and it doesn't appear to be setting the system status correctly for the process.
```python
    #(script run_test.py)
    import subprocess as proc
    command = "ipython test.py"

    p = proc.Popen( command, shell=True, cwd=None, stdout=proc.PIPE,
                stderr=proc.STDOUT )
    ( stdOut, stdErr ) = p.communicate()

    print p.returncode
    if p.returncode:
        raise Exception( stdOut )
```

In this example, "test.py" is just a simple script that raises (just raise Exception()). When I run this script from the command line (Redhat Enterprise 5.11) I get:

    > python run_test.py
    0

Now, if I change my command in "run_test.py" to use python (instead of IPython), I get:

    (using command = "python test.py")
    > python run_test.py
    1 
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "run_test.py", line 12, in <module>
        raise Exception( stdOut )
    Exception: Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "test.py", line 2, in <module>
        raise Exception()
    Exception

Any tips on how to get ipython to set the system error code correctly?
'

title: b'notebook: sys.stdout monkeypatch blocks sys.stdout.flush'
body:
b'I am trying to use multiprocessing in a notebook.  The code in [multiprocessing/forking.py](http://svn.python.org/projects/python/branches/release26-maint/Lib/multiprocessing/forking.py) uses this code to initialize the process object.  Unfortunately, the flush call blocks forever.

```
    class Popen(object):

        def __init__(self, process_obj):
            sys.stdout.flush()
            sys.stderr.flush()
            self.returncode = Non
```

This was confirmed by calling: 

```
import sys
sys.stdout.flush()
```
in the notebook.

This is with ipython 2.3.0 and pyzmq 14.3.1.'

title: b'Wrapper Kernel -> `do_shutdown` is not called when the Console is shut down.'
body:
b'If I start a wrapper kernel as such: `ipython qtconsole --kernel=my_kernel`, and exit the app via the "X" button, `do_shutdown` is called as expected.
If I start it as `ipython console --kernel=my_kernel` and exit the app via `Ctrl+D`, `y`, it is not called.  

This can be seen by installing @takluyver's bash_kernel and typing a few commands, closing the kernel properly, and reopening.  When doing this with the `console`, the history is not preserved.  '

body: b"There seems to be an issue with the timeout logic in which the sockets actually connect but the timeout for each runs its course. The behaviour I was seeing was that when I connect to an existing kernel the connection is almost instant (I'm using commit d3858463c9cd284508ac2deff9a2cde0281d20d3), but at a more recent time (around commit a10ba6f7211ffb910c23092d0aedd747d5c2fce7; note: not trying to implicate anyone here) the timeouts always run their course.\r\n\r\nI have not taken a good look at the code but after a chat with @takluyver on the IPython site I decided to make an issue to document my findings, whether there actually is an issue or not. I will try to take a harder look and find something concrete."

title: b'Race condition in slider value validation'
body:
b'```python
from IPython.html.widgets import *
from IPython.display import display
a = IntSlider(description='Test')
display(a)
```

```python
a.min = 20
a.value = 50
```

```python
print a.value
## displays 20 instead of 50. Although the slider visually is at 50
```
What is happening is, the value is set from the Javascript side on change of min. This is happening not necessarily before the value is set on the python side in the next statement. 

I was able to avoid the issue by setting the value on the min_changed function on the python side and not updating it from JS.

```python
    def _handle_min_changed(self, name, old, new):
        """Make sure the max is always >= the min and change value if needed."""
        if new > self.max:
            raise ValueError("setting min > max")
        if self.value < self.min:
            self.value = self.min
```

What do you guys think will be the best way to deal with this?

Thanks,
Srinivas'

title: b'IPython notebook slowdown when it includes huge latex expressions'
body:
b'Recently me and @eunjongkim have been working with IPython notebooks that contains a lot of SymPy generated LaTeX equations, and we are experiencing that the notebook interface becomes very sluggish and difficult to work with when it contains large latex expressions. This is not only while the expressions are being rendered, but also after mathjax has completed rendering and when the IPython kernel is not busy.

Here is an example notebook in which we are seeing this problem:

http://nbviewer.ipython.org/github/eunjongkim/reproduced-papers/blob/master/Reproduce-Nature-460-724-2009-Groblacher.ipynb

If this notebook is downloaded and opened in IPython notebook, even without being executed, just viewed, the browser almost freezes up. We see this in Safari and Chrome (in chrome the "Google Chrome Helper" process takes 100% CPU load).

After clearing all output the notebook gets fast and responsive again.'

title: b'error in examples / Notebook / Trapezoid Rule.ipynb'
body:
b"The Tapezoidal Rule notebook example has an error that invalidates its math.  The 
URL for the example is:

http://nbviewer.ipython.org/github/ipython/ipython/blob/2.x/examples/Notebook/Trapezoid%20Rule.ipynb

and is pointed to by this page:
http://nbviewer.ipython.org/github/ipython/ipython/blob/2.x/examples/Notebook/Index.ipynb

The 6th cell has this:

a, b = 1, 9
xint = x[np.logical_and(x>=a, x<=b)][::30]
yint = y[np.logical_and(x>=a, x<=b)][::30]

but that doesn't properly integrate over the range 1,9.  In fact, the example as given
only integrates over 1.005,8.543 (because of the selection of every 30th point).
Simpler and better to replace cell with:

a, b = 1, 9
xint = np.linspace(a,b,6)
yint = f(xint)

but then, unfortunately, it won't illustrate what the original author was probably 
trying to illustrate."

title: b'QTConsole broken functionality'
body:
b'I haven't updated in a while but moving to git master 2df21de, turned up 4 new issues, on top of the line editing problems I reported in #5662.

- defining a function with a very long signature makes the tooltip extend outside the screen because the width of it is not limited. I can't take a screenshot because it disappears when I try to. Example:
```python
In [7]: def f(asdkfsdfksdf=1,asdkfsdfksdf2=1,asdkfsdfksdf3=1,asdkfsdfksdf4=1,asdkfsdfksdf5=1,asdkfsdfksdf6=1,asdkfsdfksdf7=1,asdkfsdfksdf8=1,asdkfsdfksdf9=1):
   ...:     1
```
- with the signature example above, keyword completion does not work, I'm not sure what the exact trigger is.
- often a tiny, empty, tooltip appears for no reason. one instance is when the object is not defined. Try "1(" for example.
- completion used to work for filenames from the current directory, for example when entering "open('./<TAB<)" but this no longer works.
- sometime, I'm sorry I can not reproduce this reliably, the empty tooltip becomes "Stuck" and does not go away/disappear when outside a function definition, or after executing a bit of code and moving to a next line, navigating through completion items becomes extremely sluggish, and strange delays occur when typing into the console in general. (Edit: #6736  #6777)

Has QTConsole transitioned to End-Of-Life?'

'

title: b"AttributeError: 'QtInProcessShellChannel' object has no attribute '_handle_kernel_info_reply'"
body:
b"The `QtInProcessShellChannel` attempts to forward kernel info messages using a callback `_handle_kernel_info_reply` which does not exist (`kernel_mixins.py:77`)

        if msg_type == 'kernel_info_reply':
            self._handle_kernel_info_reply(msg)

Looking at the class definition above I think the fix would be:

        if msg_type == 'kernel_info_reply':
            self.kernel_info_reply.emit(msg)


"

title: b'%%cython magic module caching behavior confusing'
body:
b'The %%cython magic builds an importable module with name derived from the hash of the cell. If the hash does not change, the cell code is not recompiled.

However, this creates a confusing problem when compilation fails because, say, the path of a required library was not given correctly as an argument to %%cython. Changing the %%cython arguments and running the cell again does not recompile the module, so the failure persists.

The solution would be to derive the hash from the entire cell, including the first line.'

title: b'IPython Notebook RadioButtonsWidget value cannot be string representation of an integer.'
body:
b"A simple example:

```
def f(a, b):
  print (a,b)

b = widgets.ToggleButtonsWidget(description='kVpe:', values=[' -3', ' 0', u'3'], value=' 0')
b.on_trait_change(f, 'value')
display(b)
```
This works fine in an IPython cell and the user can click the first or second button.  However, clicking the third button, labeled '3', results in a stack trace followed by the following message:

  TraitError: The 'value_name' trait of a ToggleButtonsWidget instance must be a unicode string, but a value of 3 <type 'int'> was specified.

Note that the first two (working) buttons contain a space in front of the number.  Lacking this space, the third button issues the TraitError exception.

I am using IPython Notebook version 2.2.
(Pardon my limited experience with github markdown)."

title: b'keycodes.down used for showing tooltips?'
body:
b"Hey all!

Quick question about JS in codecell.js (line 205ish):

https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/9a0ef7371060d61415f02526caaa3916a6083d28/IPython/html/static/notebook/js/codecell.js#L205

Why are tooltips shown on 'keycodes.down'? They are _actually_ shown on `(`. However, for some reason, pressing `(` yields keycode 40 (which is the down arrow). However pressing the down arrow doesn't _also_ trigger the tooltip.

This is problematic because for IHaskell I need to override this so that tooltips are shown on space, instead of on paren. However, if I override `keycodes.down`, other things break (namely, you have to press spacebar to go down in tab completion lists!)

I am very confused and this seems like a bug / hack. What's going on?"

title: b'Changing kernels quickly leaks fds and crashes the notebook'
body:
b'If you open a notebook and then rapidly change between different kernels a couple of things happen:

* The main server process leaks fds and eventually runs out (quickly on OS X).
* The notebook IU will alter on websocket connection failures.
* The terminal will log the following:

```
[E 15:11:06.765 tornado.application] Uncaught exception in /api/kernels/4920106a-3f6c-42ac-96fb-6d6520372225/shell
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/Users/bgranger/anaconda/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tornado/websocket.py", line 322, in wrapper
        return callback(*args, **kwargs)
      File "/Users/bgranger/github/ipython/ipython/IPython/html/services/kernels/handlers.py", line 149, in on_message
        self.session.send(self.zmq_stream, msg)
      File "/Users/bgranger/github/ipython/ipython/IPython/kernel/zmq/session.py", line 658, in send
        stream.send_multipart(to_send, copy=copy)
    AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'send_multipart'
```

My guess is that the issue is caused by changing kernels before the previous kernel was fully running.'

title: b'Raw cell indentation problems with nbconvert'
body:
b'I use notebooks and nbconvert as the basis for the [seaborn](http://stanford.edu/~mwaskom/software/seaborn/) sphinx website. My basic workflow is to write notebooks with a mixture of python code cells and sphinx markup in raw text cells. See [here](https://github.com/mwaskom/seaborn/blob/master/doc/tutorial/tools/nb_to_doc.py) for the actual build script. This worked fine with 1.0, but I just built my docs (I think for the first time with 2.0; I use [runipy](https://github.com/paulgb/runipy) in the build chain and there was a lag in it supporting 2.0).

I have encountered a problem related to how nbconvert is handling the raw text. The first line of any raw text cell that follows code or image output ends up heavily indented, e.g.:

```
.. code:: python

    sns.lmplot("total_bill", "tip", tips, x_bins=8);


.. image:: quantitative_linear_models_files/quantitative_linear_models_21_0.png


                Faceted linear model plots
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
                
                The :func:`lmplot` function is built on top of a :class:`FacetGrid`. That means it's easy to visualize how this relationship changes in different subsets of your dataset
```

As you would expect, this screws up the sphinx markup. I can fix it by manually entering a blank line at the top of all my raw text cells, but that's annoying.

Does this reflect something that has changed in nbconvert for a reason?

A related issue (though one that existed in 1.0) is that nbconvert-ing to .rst doesn't add new lines after code cells, which causes a bunch of sphinx warnings. It might be worth addressing that, since it's related to the issue here (but seemingly separate).'

title: b'Multiprocessing usage results in ZMQError: Address already in use'
body:
b'Some custom python code that uses multiprocessing was occasionally throwing ZMQErrors for me when used in a notebook.

Here's a simple test case I made that always reproduces the issue for me. It creates a process that creates a process.

```
from multiprocessing import Process
def worker_worker():
    d = Process(target=worker)
    d.start()
    d.join()    
    
def worker():
    pass
    
p = Process(target=worker_worker)
p.start()
p.join()
```

Running this as a script with python, it finishes correctly. Running it in an ipython notebook causes a hang. When interrupted the exception shown is:

```
Exception in thread Thread-4:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.7_1/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/threading.py", line 810, in __bootstrap_inner

ZMQError: Address already in use

title: b'Bug: unnecessary removal of ellipses'
body:
b"One of IPythons features is removal of triple dots or triple '>' at the start of a line. This is to make it easy to copy/paste code from the python/ipython console.
This can be slightly improved, for example:
```
txt = '''.......
>>>>>>>
.......
.......
...R...
...BB..
..BRB..
.RRBR..'''
```
IPython removes the first three characters in rows 2-6.
This shouldn't have happened since the triple dots were followed by a non-whitespace character.
Code that was copied from a console will always have either a space/newline/end_of_string after the console prompt."

title: b'qtconsole truncates help'
body:
b"The Ipython shell opened with `qtconsole` option (i.e `ipython qtconsole`) truncates the help message obtained by the `??` magic. i.e
```
In [1]: import string
In [2]: string??
```
Gives:
```

            lineno = len(lines)
        raise ValueError('Invalid placeholder in string: line %d, col %d' %
                         (lineno, colno))

    def substitute(self, *args, **kws):
        if len(args) > 1:
            raise TypeError('Too many positional arguments')
        if not args:
            mapping = kws
        elif kws:
            mapping = _multimap(kws, args[0])
        else:
            mapping = args[0]
        # Helper function for .sub()
        def convert(mo):
            # Check the most common path first.
            named = mo.group('named') or mo.group('braced')
            if named is not None:
                val = mapping[named]
                # We use this idiom instead of str() because the latter will
                # fail if val is a Unicode containing non-ASCII characters.
...
```
This bug is observed on Win32 and OSX. IPython itself (without `qtconsole`) does not exhibit this problem."

title: b'Fix application name when printing subcommand help.'
body: b"I introduced this bug in PR #5754. It's fixed against master in #5796, but that won't be backported to 2.x."

title: b'fix some issues in dict key completion'
body:
b"The main change: don't auto-close contexts (str, bracket) if they are not opened within the text to match

The leading text was being omitted, causing loss of text when greedy=True. This could also affect greedy=False in some cases.

In practice, this means that strings and brackets will not be closed on dict keys when greedy=False."

title: b'horisontal scrollbar overlaps tool tip'
body:
b"If a cell has a horisontal scrollbar, and you activate a tooltip near the bottom, the tooltip appears underneath the scroll bar:
![scrollbar-over-tooltip-in-master-0ae6455](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1086081/2837094/55f8bd3a-d00e-11e3-8b06-64e9aa41164e.png)
I'm using firefox 29.0 in ubuntu 12.04, ipython master-0ae6455

It also happens with firefox 28.0 on mac osx 10.8.5, though it's not such a problem, as the scrollbar only appears when you're scrolling."

title: b'Calling `set_title` on tab widget before display causes strange behavior.'
body:
b'**To reproduce:**
```python
name = widgets.TextWidget(description='Name:')
color = widgets.DropdownWidget(description='Color:', values=['red', 'orange', 'yellow', 'green', 'blue', 'indigo', 'violet'])
page1 = widgets.ContainerWidget(children=[name, color])

age = widgets.IntSliderWidget(description='Age:', min=0, max=120, value=50)
gender = widgets.RadioButtonsWidget(description='Gender:', values=['male', 'female'])
page2 = widgets.ContainerWidget(children=[age, gender])

tabs = widgets.TabWidget(children=[page1, page2])

tabs.set_title(0, 'Name')
tabs.set_title(1, 'Details')
display(tabs)
```

After running the above code, you should have a *TabWidget* with two labeled pages, instead you get a tab widget with two closed pages "Page 0" and "Page 1".  Calling 
`tabs.selected_index = 0` does not open the first page.  Calling 
`tabs.selected_index = 1` opens the second page and causes the titles of the tabs to update.

**Workaround:**
Call set_title after displaying the *TabWidget*:
```python
name = widgets.TextWidget(description='Name:')
color = widgets.DropdownWidget(description='Color:', values=['red', 'orange', 'yellow', 'green', 'blue', 'indigo', 'violet'])
page1 = widgets.ContainerWidget(children=[name, color])

age = widgets.IntSliderWidget(description='Age:', min=0, max=120, value=50)
gender = widgets.RadioButtonsWidget(description='Gender:', values=['male', 'female'])
page2 = widgets.ContainerWidget(children=[age, gender])

tabs = widgets.TabWidget(children=[page1, page2])
display(tabs)

tabs.set_title(0, 'Name')
tabs.set_title(1, 'Details')
```'

title: b"Multi-Directory notebooks overwrite each other's checkpoints"
body:
b"IPython version: 71ff8f9523e438402f696104be44e90394bbf429 (after 2.0)

Even though I haven't seen any open issue about this yet, I believe it might be already known, given that it is mentioned here: https://github.com/ipython/ipython/wiki/IPEP-16%3A-Notebook-multi-directory-dashboard-and-URL-mapping#create-a-checkpoint

In brief, the problem is that notebooks that have the same name will write/read the same checkpoint file, regardless of the notebooks' path.

Example:
Notebooks `/test.ipynb` and `/some_path/test.ipynb` will both have their checkpoint file named `test-checkpoint.ipynb` directly under `.ipynb_checkpoints`.

The consequence of this is that if two or more notebooks located in different subdirectories happen to have the same name they will overwrite each other's checkpoints. A potential solution could be to save the checkpoints in subdirectories as well."

title: b'Changing cell type changes the cursor position.'
body:
b"Originally pointed out by James in the mailing list, changing a cell's type using modal shortcuts should not loose the Codemirror cursor position when re-entering edit mode.

To reproduce:
-new notebook
-type in the first code cell
-`esc`+`m`+`enter`
-cursor location will have reset"

body: b'If you cycle through the user interface tour too fast, the tour windows do not go away and make the notebook unusable.\r\n\r\nTo replicate, open Help->User Interface Tour in the notebook, and then press the ``\xa1\xfa`` (right arrow) key several times very quickly.'

title: b'Notebook: convert URL to link fails when delayed'
body:
b"Consider the following snippet in a notebook:
```python
for i in range(10):
    time.sleep(0.2)
    print('http://www.google.com/')
```

Only the first 2 output lines are converted into links, but when the ```sleep``` method is commented out, all 10 output lines are converted into links.

IPython version: 1.1.0
Python version: 2.7.6
OS: Windows 8.1 64bit"

title: b'IPython on Windows leaks connection files for secondary kernels in qtconsole'
body: b"If you start a second kernel using the file menu and close it the connection file is not deleted since the code in IPython/kernel/manager.py shutdown_kernel doesn't call cleanup_connection_file and cleanup_ipc_files on windows due to an `if` that does a return."

title: b'ipython console ignoring some stream messages?'
body:
b'In JuliaLang/IJulia.jl#153, @cbecker commented that `ipython console` does not seem to get standard output (which is sent to the console via `stream` messages according to the message spec).  I confirmed this:
```
$ ipython console --profile julia 
Python 2.7.1 (r271:86832, Jul 31 2011, 19:30:53) 
Type "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.

IPython 1.1.0 -- An enhanced Interactive Python.
?         -> Introduction and overview of IPython's features.
%quickref -> Quick reference.
help      -> Python's own help system.
object?   -> Details about 'object', use 'object??' for extra details.

IPython profile: julia
Starting kernel event loops.

In [1]: 

In [1]: ccall(:printf, Cint, (Ptr{Uint8},), "Hello world!\n")
Out[1]: 13
```
It works (prints `"Hello world!"`) in both the `qtconsole` and `notebook` front-ends, so it seems like it may be a bug in the `console` front-end.'

title: b'Raw cell placeholder is not removed when you edit the cell'
body: b"Cell placeholders are used when a cell is in the rendered state and its contents are empty. However, when you go to edit the cell, the placeholder should be removed, leaving an empty cell in which to type. This doesn't happen for raw cells."

title: b'display_method of objects with custom __getattr__'
body:
b"Some objects such as pymongo collections implement a custom  `__getattr__` method that always  retursn an object.

Then for the IPython display there is https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/master/IPython/core/displayhook.py#L245 which will call the `_ipython_display_` attribute returned by `__getattr__` and produce unpredictable behaviour; best case just an error, like:

````
TypeError: 'Collection' object is not callable. If you meant to call the '_ipython_display_'
 method on a 'Collection' object it is failing because no such method exists.
````
Probably can be considered a bug of pymongo, but may be worth considering to check for existence in `__dict__` rather than getattr."

title: b'Flexbox CSS specificity bugs'
body:
b"I have a [notebook](https://github.com/jdfreder/ipython-d3/blob/master/demo%20factor.ipynb) (part of https://github.com/jdfreder/ipython-d3/) which uses the following code to center align contents within a box:

```python
box.add_class('align-center')
box.add_class('center')
```

Unfortunately, this code doesn't seem to work always.  

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/3292874/2152408/d567e6fe-9418-11e3-828e-54767c36bafd.png)

The specificity of the widget-container CSS is equal to the specificity of the flexbox alignment classes which leaves the browsers to make the decision of which class is more important.  The widget-container inherits from the vbox class in LESS which defines default alignments.  Since the LESS loses the inheritance structure when compiled, the default alignments are defined on the widget-container class (from the browsers point of view).

One possible, hackish, solution is to !important the alignment properties in the alignment classes.  Maybe someone who is more familiar "

title: b'Client.map is not fault tolerant'
body:
b'Hi, I have an issue where Client.map is not fault tolerant. I would like to use IPython.parallel to simply speed up long map operations using multiple computers, but I would like it to be fault tolerant so that I could turn off engines on certain computers when I require the computer.
Here is the offending code:
```
def job(i):
    import os, time
    time.sleep(5)
    return os.getpid()

from IPython.parallel import Client
c = Client()
lbv = c.load_balanced_view()
res = lbv.map_sync(job, range(20))
print(len(res), len(set(res)))
```
I start up a ipcontroller and two ipengines, I then run the code; as expected it prints out `20 2`.
I then rerun the code. This time, in the middle of the map, I start up a third engine. Happily, the controller starts using the new engine for the current map, and the output was `20 3`.
Unfortunately, when I run the code a third time, and close the third engine in the middle of the map, the controller prints out ten 'hearbeat missed' messages, and then prints out the error: 
```
ERROR:root:Error in delayed callback
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Anaconda\envs\py33\lib\site-packages\zmq\eventloop\ioloop.py", line 554, in _run
    self.callback()
  File "C:\Anaconda\envs\py33\lib\site-packages\IPython\parallel\controller\scheduler.py", line 333, in <lambda>
    dc = ioloop.DelayedCallback(lambda : self.handle_stranded_tasks(uid), 5000, self.loop)
  File "C:\Anaconda\envs\py33\lib\site-packages\IPython\parallel\controller\scheduler.py", line 365, in handle_stranded_tasks
    raw_reply = list(map(zmq.Message, self.session.serialize(msg, ident=idents)))
  File "C:\Anaconda\envs\py33\lib\site-packages\IPython\kernel\zmq\session.py", line 535, in serialize
    self.pack(msg['metadata']),
  File "C:\Anaconda\envs\py33\lib\site-packages\IPython\kernel\zmq\session.py", line 83, in <lambda>
    json_packer = lambda obj: jsonapi.dumps(obj, default=date_default)
  File "C:\Anaconda\envs\py33\lib\site-packages\zmq\utils\jsonapi.py", line 72, in dumps
    return _squash_unicode(jsonmod.dumps(o, **kwargs))
  File "C:\Anaconda\envs\py33\lib\json\__init__.py", line 243, in dumps
    **kw).encode(obj)
  File "C:\Anaconda\envs\py33\lib\json\encoder.py", line 191, in encode
    chunks = self.iterencode(o, _one_shot=True)
  File "C:\Anaconda\envs\py33\lib\json\encoder.py", line 249, in iterencode
    return _iterencode(o, 0)
  File "C:\Anaconda\envs\py33\lib\site-packages\IPython\utils\jsonutil.py", line 99, in date_default
    raise TypeError("%r is not JSON serializable"%obj)
TypeError: b'd6c6e1b5-a7e2-4672-a23e-65a425a76269' is not JSON serializable
```
The code that called the map function is stuck with a 'Kernel busy' message.
Note that adding the line `lbv.set_flags(retries=10)` does not affect the outcome.

My IPython version info:
```
{'codename': 'An Afternoon Hack',

title: b'Consistent approach for HTML/JS output on nbviewer'
body:
b"This is probably more to do with nbviewer than IPython, but I wanted to start the discussion here.  Pinging @wrobstory @jakevdp @rgbkrk as well.

The issue is that nbviewer doesn't provide the same runtime environment as the live notebook. There are a couple of differences:

* JS output is not run at all. This forces people to put JS code in `<script>` tags to get it to work with nbviewer.
* jQuery is loaded at the bottom of the page, so any JS code that does get run in script tags doesn't have jQuery. This means that proejcts like mpld3 have to do wonky things like this because `$.getScript` doesn't exist:

https://github.com/jakevdp/mpld3/blob/master/mpld3/_objects.py#L192

* require.js is not on the page. Libraries such as d3 exhibit different initialization logic if require is defined. Both vincent and mpld3 have to have special cases to cover nbviewer right now as it doesn't have require.js on the page.

Here is a notebook on nbviewer that shows these issues:

http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/ellisonbg/8906675

Here is my proposal for 2.0:

* In the nbviewer template add `require.js` at the top of the page (above the body).
* Move jQuery to the top of the page (above the body).
* Enable the display of JS output.

This should unify the live notebook and nbviewer for 2.0 at a reasonable level."

title: b'Python Lists translated to javascript objects in widgets'
body:
b'From @ChakriCherukuri:

I just got the latest code from master and I am trying to create my custom widgets. One thing I noticed is that List() traitlet is no longer being mapped to an array on JS side. It is now mapped
into an object something like {0: v1, 1: v2, 2: v3, ...} as opposed to an array like [v1, v2, v3, ...]. It would be great if someone can look into this issue.

From @jasongrout: It looks like the javascript unpacker should be checking to see if the value is `$.isArray` before checking to see if it is an object here and handling arrays by creating a javascript array: https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/master/IPython/html/static/notebook/js/widgets/widget.js#L225.

Sources: https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/4374#issuecomment-33743651 (initial bug report), https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/4374#issuecomment-33744219 and https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/4374#issuecomment-33744361 track down the problem and outline a fix.
'

title: b'Fix pretty reprs of super() objects'
body:
b'Prompted by [this SO question](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/21531713/why-does-ipython-display-super-objects-differently-from-the-regular-python-int).

The problem:

```
In [1]: class A(object):
    pass
   ...: 

In [2]: class B(A): pass

In [3]: class C(B): pass

In [4]: c = C()

In [5]: super(B, c)
Out[5]: <super: __main__.C, <__main__.C at 0x2a772d0>>

In [6]: repr(super(B, c))
Out[6]: "<super: <class 'B'>, <C object>>"

In [7]: super(B)
Out[7]: <super: None, None>

In [8]: repr(super(B))
Out[8]: "<super: <class 'B'>, NULL>"
```

Afterwards:

```
In [6]: super(B, c)
Out[6]: <super: __main__.B, <__main__.C at 0x1fbb6d0>>

In [7]: super(B)
Out[7]: <super: __main__.B, None>
```'

title: b'Inconsistent %matplotlib qt behavior'
body:
b"Evaluating a cell beginning with the `%matplotlib qt` magic and immediately following with commands to [Mayavi](https://github.com/enthought/mayavi) cause the kernel to freeze. The Mayavi window opens correctly and responds to user input, but the cell never yields control back to the user.

If instead, a cell containing `%matplotlib qt` in isolation is run, it returns without issue. Subsequently issuing Mayavi commands in a separate cell work as expected, returning immediately.

[This notebook](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/jabooth/8770104) gives a minimal demonstration of the problem, as well as some further diagnostic information.

Note that the problem is confirmed to exist on OS X on a [recent master](https://github.com/ipython/ipython/commit/9b8c058d4ef1667b292fea5e5a365aa545da6112) and on Linux (thanks @fperez)

Note that this bug only occurs the first time the `%matplotlib qt` command is executed - subsequent calls (e.g. after switching to `%matplotlib inline` and back to `%matplotlib qt` with commands immediately following in the qt enabled cell) work fine.

title: b'reveal: ipython css overrides reveal themes'
body:
b"Migrated from https://github.com/ipython/nbconvert/issues/131
Original author @keflavich 

---

The Reveal themes don't work with ipython notebooks, I think because the notebooks override the theme css.  For example:

If I use the night theme:
http://keflavich.github.io/astr2600_notebooks/Lecture23_DataFitting.html?theme=night#/
the background os overridden by a `body {background-color:white;}` setting.   However, if I use sky:
http://keflavich.github.io/astr2600_notebooks/Lecture23_DataFitting.html?theme=sky#/
the background image shows up as expected.  

Similarly, the text does not change appropriately.

Is it possible to support reveal themes?  Or are there ipython-notebook-compatible reveal themes?"

title: b'reveal: slides that are too big?'
body:
b"Migrated from https://github.com/ipython/nbconvert/issues/123
Original author keflavich 

---

Is there any way to split up slides that are too big to fit on a single Reveal slide, e.g. by having the source & output on different slides?

Here's an example of what I'd like fixed:
http://slideviewer.herokuapp.com/urls/raw.github.com/keflavich/astr2600_notebooks/master/SamplingFromDistributions.ipynb#/18

either by making different parts into sub-slides or allowing the scrollbar to function.  

Let me know if this is really an issue with Reveal, and maybe I'll try to ask upstream.

(but huge +1 to making Reveal work!  It's awesome!)"

title: b'TeX produced cannot be converted to PDF'
body:
b"This issue needs to be verified as fixed before it can be closed.  See the notebook provided below.

Migrated from https://github.com/ipython/nbconvert/issues/118
Original author @yoavram

---

I either convert ipynb to tex file and try to convert it to PDF with pandoc or TeXworks, or I try to convert ipynb directly to pdf, I always get this error:

Runaway argument?
{Extended Introduction to Computer Science with Python,
! Paragraph ended before \@sect was complete.

\par
l.129 Tel-Aviv University, Spring 2013}
for this input https://raw.github.com/yoavram/CS1001.py/master/recitation4.ipynb.
I'm using the latest nbconvert (I do git pull before running) - commit 670c867.

Thanks"

title: b'Heading/cells positioning problem and cell output wrapping'
body:
b"Migrated from https://github.com/ipython/nbconvert/issues/93
Original author @montefra 

---

When converting a notebook to latex I've noticed two issues comparing the notebook with the pdf created by latex. The dvi opened with okular has the same layout but the cells show a black background instead of the light gray of the pdf. I'm on Kubuntu 12.10, ipython 0.13.1, nbconvert from today's master. I see the same using latex and pdflatex.

The problems:
1. Heading 4 are converted to paragraphs and are all out of place with respect to the cells where they should be. It seems that markdown cells are where they have to be.
2. the output of the cells is within verbatim, thus long lines go out of the boundaries. This tex.stackexchange suggests spverbatim or listings as possible substitutes. If any of the two comes with (most) of latex distribution might be worth thinking about using it

ps: I hope that it is possible to get the dvi."

title: b'Trouble finding ipynb path in Windows 8'
body:
b"Migrated from https://github.com/ipython/nbconvert/issues/72
Original author @chrismv48

---

Hey guys, a relative newbie here when it comes to using the windows command prompt and to github in general so this could possibly be a silly question, but I've spend over an hour on this and have searched far and wide with no solution.

Case:

installed all dependencies
downloaded nbconvert repo to dir: C:\Python27\Lib\nbconvert-master
added environment path variables for the nbconvert base dir, as well as the css and js subdirectories
added environment path variable for dir where ipython notebook is saved
tested that nbconvert was install with 'nbconvert.py -h'. This works.
tried to convert notebook with 'nbconvert.py -f blogger-html test.ipynb'. Get the following error:
IOError: [Error 2] No such file or directory: 'test.ipynb'

I tried copying test.ipynb to the nbconvert directory and still get the same error. What am I doing wrong?"

title: b'Eliminating display of intermediate stages in progress bars'
body:
b"Migrated from https://github.com/ipython/nbconvert/issues/185
Original author @fonnesbeck

---

When working with notebooks that use code that generates visual outputs such as progress bars, displaying them either in nbviewer or as an export format (e.g. latex) results in the intermediate outputs from such components are printed, taking up a huge amount of document space. These need to be manually deleted in order for the document to be usable.

Here is what it looks like:

![example](http://f.cl.ly/items/2d0d1N021V1w35402e3o/Screen%20Shot%202013-06-18%20at%202.26.44%20PM.png)

[Here's an example notebook with this behavior](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/urls/raw.github.com/pymc-devs/pymc/glm/pymc/examples/GLM.ipynb)"

the following snippet :

P(E)   = {n \choose k} p^k (1-p)^{ n-k}

title: b'Too many files open when starting and stopping kernel repeatedly'
body:
b'The following code:

```
from IPython.kernel import KernelManager

for i in range(1000):
    km = KernelManager()
    km.start_kernel(extra_arguments=['--pylab=inline'])
    kc = km.client()
    kc.start_channels()
    kc.stop_channels()
    km.shutdown_kernel(now=True)
```

causes the following exception after ~27 iterations:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test_ipython.py", line 6, in <module>
  File "/Users/tom/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages/IPython/kernel/manager.py", line 202, in start_kernel
  File "/Users/tom/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages/IPython/kernel/connect.py", line 481, in write_connection_file
  File "/Users/tom/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages/IPython/kernel/connect.py", line 110, in write_connection_file
  File "/opt/local/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/socket.py", line 187, in __init__
socket.error: [Errno 24] Too many open files
```

It looks like some file handles are not getting closed? I had a look and didn't see anything obvious. This is relevant for e.g. [runipy](https://github.com/paulgb/runipy) because it starts and stops the kernel each time a different notebook is run.

(also, the error occurs even if I set ``now=False``).
'

body: b'Completer does not seem to pick/filter when you type. \r\n\r\nkeypress seem not to be forwarded to codemirror.'

title: b'rubbish null bytes at the end of notebook file'
body:
b'Sometimes it happens to me that at the very end of my notebook files null bytes (0x00) are appended (I observed between 2 and several hundreds) . The notebook files fail to load ('bad request') the next time. Also nbconvert fails. Luckily such an file can be resurrected by deleting the null bytes. 
This only happens sometimes, but with a file containing a lot of inline pylab figures (png) and heavy recreating of figures this happens quite often. 

I am using recent ipython from git, with python 2.7.6 on osx 10.9.

As Matthias Bussonnier pointed out on the dev list, this is "**really** weird", since saving a notebook uses the json module from the standard Python libraries, I checked this too. Possibly this problem is not related to IPython. 

Gregor'

title: b'Error in Session.send_raw()'
body:
b'I believe that the line:
https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/master/IPython/kernel/zmq/session.py#L682

stream.send_multipart(msg_list, flags, copy=copy)

should be:

stream.send_multipart(to_send, flags, copy=copy)
'

title: b'running ipython on python files adds an extra traceback frame'
body:
b'If you make a file `test.py` that throws a trivial error, and then run it with `ipython test.py`, you get an extra frame in the traceback:

    root@8e0bcc11822a:~# ipython test.py
    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    ZeroDivisionError                         Traceback (most recent call last)
    /usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/IPython/utils/py3compat.pyc in execfile(fname, *where)
        173             else:
        174                 filename = fname
    --> 175             __builtin__.execfile(filename, *where)

    /home/coderpad/test.py in <module>()
          2 while x < 10:
          3   x += 1
    ----> 4   10 / (5 - x)
          5
          6 print x

    ZeroDivisionError: integer division or modulo by zero
    root@8e0bcc11822a:~# ipython --version
    0.12.1

Is there some way to configure the traceback formatted for file runs to drop the topmost frame? I know that the console does this in places, but I have no idea how to achieve that for script runs.'

title: b'File Upload URL set incorrectly'
body:
b'After uploading a file via the dashboard, whether from Drag and Drop or the file selection dialog, the URL initially gets set improperly.

The file does get uploaded according to the current path context, but the uri is set to 

`/notebooks/%5Bobject%20Object%5D/notebook_name.ipynb`

Refreshing the page fixes the problem.'

title: b'IPython.lib.editorhooks broken on windows'
body: b"The hook that this module installs uses the `pipes` modules' `quote` function to quote the filename to open. Sadly on Windows this function still uses single quote which the shell doesn't understand, instead of double quotes, meaning the hook doesn't work."

Specifically, clicking into a large cell will arbitrarily scroll upward from the location where I click. I've prepared [a movie that shows this behavior explicitly](http://d.pr/v/LTzy).\r\n\r\nRunning in Safari 7.0.1 on OS X 10.9.1 using IPython built from master 2 days ago."

title: b'Did updates to ipython_directive bork support for cython magic snippets?'
body:
b"...I wish to register a [complaint](https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/4570#issuecomment-30558161).

re #4570, I'd be glad for pandas to get rid of it's copy of ipython_directive
and to that end, I rebased the pandas tweaks on the version in ipython/master (0355d3d).

I cannot however get cython magic code snippets to work with the updated version,
and I've been unable to locate other packages which do this as a sanity check.
Assuming it should work out of the box rather then as a tweak pandas added and 
which I failed to carry over.

Here's an example from current pandas docs which now fails to render properly.

````
.. ipython:: python

   %load_ext cythonmagic


Now, let's simply copy our functions over to cython as is (the suffix
is here to distinguish between function versions):

.. ipython::

   In [2]: %%cython
      ...: def f_plain(x):
      ...:     return x * (x - 1)
      ...: def integrate_f_plain(a, b, N):
      ...:     s = 0
      ...:     dx = (b - a) / N
      ...:     for i in range(N):
      ...:         s += f_plain(a + i * dx)
      ...:     return s * dx
      ...:

.. note::

  If you're having trouble pasting the above into your ipython, you may need
  to be using bleeding edge ipython for paste to play well with cell magics.


.. ipython:: python

   %timeit df.apply(lambda x: integrate_f_plain(x['a'], x['b'], x['N']), axis=1)

```

Is it my fault or is there an issue with the new version?

cc @takluyver, @jorisvandenbossche

"

title: b'Tab completion on `__` deletes line in notebook'
body:
b'In the notebook:

```python
x = object
x.__dict__.__<tab><tab>
```

First tab will create a drop down. the second one will delete the whole line.'

  File "/home/takluyver/.local/lib/python3.3/site-packages/IPython/config/application.py", line 527, in _load_config_files
    log.debug("Loaded config file: %s", loader.full_filename)
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'debug'
```

`_load_config_files` has a log parameter with a default of None. It should either be required, or it should do something sensible when it gets the default.'

title: b'Firefox 26/OS X - typing does not initially show up in cells in IPython Notebook'
body:
b"Firefox recently released v.26, which from what I gather has some fairly major changes to a bunch of stuff. I just ran `ipython3 notebook` for the first time since the upgrade, started a fresh notebook, and then noticed that the characters I was typing in the first cell were not showing up. If I tried to submit the cell with `Shift-Enter` nothing happened - it was like submitting an empty cell. However, I then discovered that if I typed for a little bit, and then hit the left or right arrow key, the commands I had been typing showed up. If I continue typing nothing shows, but hitting an arrow key again makes it show up. Submitting the cell then works like normal. This doesn't appear to be an issue with any plugins, as disabling them has no effect.

Suspecting it may have had something to do with the Firefox upgrade I downloaded v.25, disabled automatic upgrades, reconnected to the same notebook server, and everything worked fine, so it definitely seems to be something with FF26. I then started up my Windows 7 virtual machine in VMWare, but was unable to replicate the issue, so it may be specific to OS X (I haven't had a chance to test it on Linux).

I use MacPorts to manage many of my Python packages, so I'm a little hesitant to upgrade to the `master` branch, but if you need me to for further troubleshooting I certainly can. Please let me know if you need any other information.

```python
In [62]: print(IPython.sys_info())
{'codename': 'An Afternoon Hack',

title: b'Qtconsole docstring pop-up fails on method containing defaulted enum argument'
body:
b'[We've found](http://trac.mantidproject.org/mantid/ticket/8422) that an error is generated in the (admittedly rare) situation where a C++ enum is exposed to Python via boost python and included in a python function as a default to an argument. This is seen in IPython 1.1 and the current tip of master.

Here's the simplest example I could come up with, though it does still require compiling C++ and linking to boost python. In a C++ file:
```c++
#include <boost/python.hpp>

enum MyEnum
{
  Red,
  Yellow,
  Blue
};

BOOST_PYTHON_MODULE(enum_test)
{
  using namespace boost::python;

  enum_<MyEnum>("MyEnum")
    .value("Red", Red)
    .value("Yellow", Yellow)
    .value("Blue", Blue);
}
```
This should be compiled to a shared library with something like `gcc -fPIC -I /usr/include/python2.6 -shared -o enum_test.so enum_test.cpp -lboost_python`

Then, in the IPython qtconsole enter:
```
In [1]: import enum_test

In [2]: def MyFunc(color = enum_test.MyEnum.Red):
   ...:     pass
   ...: 

In [3]: MyFunc(
```
On typing the opening parenthesis a stack trace will appear that culminates in:
```
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/IPython/kernel/zmq/session.py", line 83, in <lambda>
    json_unpacker = lambda s: extract_dates(jsonapi.loads(s))
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/site-packages/zmq/utils/jsonapi.py", line 81, in loads
    return jsonmod.loads(s, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/site-packages/simplejson/__init__.py", line 307, in loads
    return _default_decoder.decode(s)
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/site-packages/simplejson/decoder.py", line 335, in decode
    obj, end = self.raw_decode(s, idx=_w(s, 0).end())
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/site-packages/simplejson/decoder.py", line 353, in raw_decode
    raise ValueError("No JSON object could be decoded")
```

The string that's going into the raw_decode function of decoder.py and leads to the exception is:
```
{"base_class":"<type 'function'>","init_definition":null,"type_name":"function","name":"MyFunc","isclass":null,"namespace":"Interactive","isalias":false,"init_docstring":null,"argspec":{"args":["color"],"varkw":null,"defaults":[Red],"varargs":null},"source":null,"length":null,"call_def":null,"call_docstring":null,"file":"/home/enumproblem/<ipython-input-2-b6e10dea3e06>","string_form":"<function MyFunc at 0x16a8de8>","found":true,"class_docstring":null,"definition":"\u001b[0mMyFunc\u001b[0m\u001b[1;33m(\u001b[0m\u001b[0mcolor\u001b[0m\u001b[1;33m=\u001b[0m\u001b[0menum_test\u001b[0m\u001b[1;33m.\u001b[0m\u001b[0mMyEnum\u001b[0m\u001b[1;33m.\u001b[0m\u001b[0mRed\u001b[0m\u001b[1;33m)\u001b[0m\u001b[1;33m\u001b[0m\u001b[0m\n","docstring":"<no docstring>","ismagic":false}
```'

title: b'Failed save due to full disk unrecoverable'
body:
b'While editing an ipython notebook, a disk filled up (due to a different process dumping data).  When I tried to save the notebook, it returned an error message that the saving failed. Being confused, I closed down (as I had saved it just recently) everything, restarted the notebook, and discovered that the .ipynb had been corrupted by the incomplete save, and was now lost. 

The log looked something like this:

2013-11-22 12:07:28.043 [tornado.general] WARNING | 400 PUT /notebooks/fdcdf492-1448-4c18-9cf5-c4babb5640fd (127.0.0.1): Unexpected error while autosaving notebook: [Errno 122] Disk quota exceeded

then:

2013-11-22 12:07:37.748 [tornado.general] WARNING | 400 GET /notebooks/944c31b5-ce89-453c-bc37-d3960b4270c7?_=1385150857316 (127.0.0.1): Unreadable Notebook: Notebook does not appear to be JSON: '{\n "metadata": {'

Not sure if there is a robust fix for handling what is really an error on my side of  having a full disk, but figured I should still report it.  

Thanks!'

title: b'NBconvert fails with unicode errors when `--stdout` and file redirection is specified and HTML entities are present'
body:
b"I'm not sure if this is a bug, but we just got caught by this in:https://github.com/swcarpentry/bc/pull/163

To reproduce, create an IPython Notebook with any HTML entity such as:

`×`

Then try running nbconvert with --stdout with output to a file.

```
ipython nbconvert --stdout test.ipynb > test.html
```

This will break, although:

```
ipython nbconvert --stdout test.ipynb
```

and

```
ipython nbconvert test.ipynb
```

both work.

"

title: b'Qtconsole cannot print an ISO8601 date at nanosecond precision'
body:
b'This is seen in 1.1. Entering the following produces an error:
```python
print '2013-11-05T16:36:22.100000002'
````

The pertinent part of the error trace shows that strptime is raising an uncaught ValueError because it's not getting a format that matches up with that given in the ISO8601 variable:
````
File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/IPython/utils/jsonutil.py", line 70, in extract_dates
    obj[k] = extract_dates(v)
File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/IPython/utils/jsonutil.py", line 79, in extract_dates
    obj = datetime.strptime(notz, ISO8601)
File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/_strptime.py", line 328, in _strptime
    data_string[found.end():])
ValueError: unconverted data remains: 000
ERROR:root:Exception in callback <zmq.eventloop.stack_context._StackContextWrapper object at 0x7f0128021838>
````
We came across this because our application exposes Boost Posix Time (where we use nanosecond precision) to python.'

title: b'Exception chaining in Python 3 tracebacks'
body:
b'In Python 3, exceptions raised in an except handler carry a reference to the original exception. The default tracebacks show this, but at present, our tracebacks (IPython.core.ultratb) don't.

```
Python 3.3.2+ (default, Sep 19 2013, 15:29:36) 
[GCC 4.8.1] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> try: foo
... except: 1/0
... 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
NameError: name 'foo' is not defined

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 2, in <module>
ZeroDivisionError: division by zero
>>> 



Python 3.3.2+ (default, Sep 19 2013, 15:29:36) 
Type "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.

IPython 0.13.2 -- An enhanced Interactive Python.
?         -> Introduction and overview of IPython's features.
%quickref -> Quick reference.
help      -> Python's own help system.
object?   -> Details about 'object', use 'object??' for extra details.
>>> try: foo
    except: 1/0
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ZeroDivisionError                         Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-1-33129b9a40ca> in <module>()
      1 try: foo
----> 2 except: 1/0

ZeroDivisionError: division by zero
```'

title: b'sync_imports() fails in python 3.3'
body:
b'builtins.__import__ no longer seems to use level=-1,
view.py, line 481:
if level == -1 and key not in modules:

This if never get executed and nothing is imported on engines because level defaults to 0 for python 3.3

I changed to:
if level == 0 and key not in modules:
Which works for me, but is probably not a good fix.'

title: b'IPython crashes when import pylib'
body:
b"I found that IPython (1.0, 1.1) crashes when importing the latest pylib package on windows.
The reason to that is that pylib defines in its module terminalwriter.py argtypes, and restype property to some windows functions in ctypes (GetStdHandle, SetConsoleTextAttribute, GetConsoleScreenBufferInfo) and it crashes some how with how IPython deals with that. my fix was just to comment out those lines in pylib terminalwriter module (relevant lines are  285-298, It works fine without them) but you would probably want to fix this by dealing better with  :) 

another way to recreate this issue is by pasting the following code in IPython.

```python

import ctypes
from ctypes import wintypes
SHORT = ctypes.c_short
class COORD(ctypes.Structure):
    _fields_ = [('X', SHORT),
                ('Y', SHORT)]
class SMALL_RECT(ctypes.Structure):
    _fields_ = [('Left', SHORT),
                ('Top', SHORT),
                ('Right', SHORT),
                ('Bottom', SHORT)]
class CONSOLE_SCREEN_BUFFER_INFO(ctypes.Structure):
    _fields_ = [('dwSize', COORD),
                ('dwCursorPosition', COORD),
                ('wAttributes', wintypes.WORD),
                ('srWindow', SMALL_RECT),
                ('dwMaximumWindowSize', COORD)]

_GetStdHandle = ctypes.windll.kernel32.GetStdHandle
_GetStdHandle.argtypes = [wintypes.DWORD]
_GetStdHandle.restype = wintypes.HANDLE
def GetStdHandle(kind):
    return _GetStdHandle(kind)

SetConsoleTextAttribute = ctypes.windll.kernel32.SetConsoleTextAttribute
SetConsoleTextAttribute.argtypes = [wintypes.HANDLE, wintypes.WORD]
SetConsoleTextAttribute.restype = wintypes.BOOL

_GetConsoleScreenBufferInfo = \
    ctypes.windll.kernel32.GetConsoleScreenBufferInfo
_GetConsoleScreenBufferInfo.argtypes = [wintypes.HANDLE,
                            ctypes.POINTER(CONSOLE_SCREEN_BUFFER_INFO)]
_GetConsoleScreenBufferInfo.restype = wintypes.BOOL
```"

title: b'Double output on Ctrl-enter-enter'
body:
b'(Reported by Fujun Du on the mailing list)

When I run a cell in place with "Control-Enter" to make a plot, and if I press the key combination very quickly twice (namely, press "Control-Enter-Enter"), I will have two copies of the same plot shown below the cell.

This is nothing important but just for you to know the issue. To reproduce the behavior, I guess the computation in the cell must take quite some time to finish (to be slower than the key press). For example, put the following code into a new cell and press "Control-Enter-Enter" quickly you will get two output "xxx".  In case your computer is very fast, add one or a few more zeros to the xrange:

```
import math
for i in xrange(1000000):
    a = math.sin(i)
print 'xxx'
```'

title: b"autoreload shouldn't rely on .pyc modification times"
body:
b'This can fail if:

- Writing .pyc files is disabled, e.g. by setting $PYTHONDONTWRITEBYTECODE.
- The module has been imported or reloaded by another process before we check it, or explicitly compiled using pycompile.

To handle this better, autoreload could keep a cache of the modified time of each module, and then check against that rather than the .pyc timestamp.'

title: b'Nbconvert [windows]: Inconsistent line endings in markdown cells exported to latex '
body:
b"I'm getting what looks like inconsistent line endings in the output of markdown cells, which is causing latex to complain about runaway arguments and paragraphs ending early.

The exact error is:

    ! Paragraph ended before \ttl@straight@i was complete

And looking at the offending line in the `.tex` file (in emacs):

    \subsection{ Text that doesn't have line breaks in it in the markdown cell^M^M    
     but does seem to have two CRLF's (judging by the ^M's), and a LF here.}

Taking the `^M`'s out will allow pdflatex to produce the output, but there are still ^M's scattered throughout the document. 

As a guess it's that [Pandoc explicitly expects UTF-8] (http://johnmacfarlane.net/pandoc/README.html#using-pandoc), and somehow the subprocess is piping in CP-850 or similar windows encoding and pandoc is outputting some combination of the two line endings.

I've tried to recreate the issue just with Pandoc, inputting various encoding schemes but I couldn't recreate it.

Alternatively, it may be the utf-8 encoding casting that occurs in `IPython/nbconvert/utils/pandoc.py` which is adding LF but not removing the CRLFs ( but I'm still not sure why there are any line breaks as the original cell doesn't have them).

Sys info.

    {'codename': 'An Afternoon Hack',
     'commit_hash': '02da31c',
     'commit_source': 'installation',
     'default_encoding': 'cp850',
     'ipython_path': 'C:\\Python27\\lib\\site-packages\\IPython',
     'ipython_version': '1.0.0',
     'os_name': 'nt',
     'platform': 'Windows-7-6.1.7601-SP1',
     'sys_executable': 'C:\\Python27\\python.exe',
     'sys_platform': 'win32',
     'sys_version': '2.7.3 |EPD_free 7.3-2 (32-bit)| (default, Apr 12 2012, 14:30:3
     ) [MSC v.1500 32 bit (Intel)]'}"

title: b'kernel dies with " : cannot connect to X server " attempting to plot when running under byobu'
body:
b"I often run `ipython notebook` from a `byobu` (aka `screen`) on Ubuntu. In my `byobu` terminals, the `DISPLAY` environment variable is not set, and as a result attempting to create a matplotlib plot results the kernel crashing with:

   : cannot connect to X server 

I can fix it by executing `export DISPLAY=:0` before I run `ipython notebook`.

I guess this is more a problem with `byobu`/`screen`, bit it'd might be useful to try `:0` (or it's equivalent on other OS's) if `DISPLAY` is empty.

At the very least, a more informative error message to the log is in order - it took some digging in the source code to track it down..

ps: [This pull request](https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/3883) may have some relevance??"

title: b'think more carefully about text wrapping in nbconvert'
body: b'1. we should never perform any transforms of any kind on raw cells, not even wrapping\r\n2. colored output is wrapped based on the length including ANSI escapes, so they can end up as super short lines.'
